awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mixed-Autonomy Traffic Networks: Routing Games and Learning Human Choice Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Autonomous and connected vehicles are soon becoming a significant part of roads normally used by human drivers. Such vehicles hold the promise of safer streets, better fuel efficiency, more flexibility in tailoring to specific drivers’ needs, and time savings. However, the appearance of autonomous vehicles driving on roads shared by human-driven cars introduce many interesting and timely challenges. The goal of this proposal is to study (i) traffic networks with mixed autonomy where a fraction of cars are autonomous and the rest are human-driven, and (ii) how humans choose their routes in a traffic network given different options of autonomous service and prices. By studying models of humans’ choices and investigating the characterizations of traffic flow in networks with mixed autonomy, the project develops routing policies to lead the network to an efficient equilibrium with low average latency.

This proposal aims to study routing games and human choice models for traffic networks with mixed autonomy. Many studies have shown that mobility can be enhanced in traffic networks such as freeways or signalized intersections when all cars are autonomous; however, such improvement is far from clear for a network with mixed autonomy. The goal of this project is to study the game theory of mixed-autonomy traffic networks and control the autonomous cars’ routing decisions such that the system reaches an optimum equilibrium. Moreover, a novel approach in learning human choices of prices in autonomous transportation services versus latency, or travel time, is developed. Finally, using the well-known fundamental diagram of traffic and cell-transmission model, a dynamic mixed-autonomy traffic model is introduced. Using this dynamic model, we will leverage tools from reinforcement learning to route autonomous cars dynamically and optimally. The proposed research considers both theoretical study of routing games as well as implementation of the developed algorithms in traffic simulators, in particular simulation of Urban Mobility (SUMO). The learned human choice models will also be validated through human subject studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
Autonomous and connected vehicles are poised to become a significant presence on roads traditionally dominated by human drivers. These vehicles promise numerous benefits, including safer streets, improved fuel efficiency, greater customization to individual driver needs, and time savings. Beyond these advantages, autonomous vehicles profoundly impact traffic flow, offering benefits at both individual and network levels. By forming platoons and maintaining shorter following distances, autonomous vehicles can increase road capacity, enhance throughput, and reduce fuel consumption. They also help smooth out shockwaves and instabilities that commonly occur in traffic congestion caused by human drivers. Moreover, autonomous vehicles can encourage drivers to choose routes that minimize overall traffic delays, promoting more efficient use of road networks.

These advancements bring both challenges and opportunities, particularly in designing efficient routing algorithms to manage congestion on shared roads. This proposal focuses on studying routing games and human choice models to advance next-generation intelligent transportation systems.

On the theoretical and modeling side, we have developed innovative traffic models and analyzed equilibria in mixed-autonomy networks. Specifically, we formulated a formal model that captures the relationship between traffic flow, latency, and density in mixed-autonomy scenarios (measured in vehicles per second). Additionally, we leveraged game theory to rigorously characterize the associated congestion game and its equilibria. We also designed dynamic routing and pricing strategies by leveraging learning techniques such as reinforcement learning. These strategies optimize the routing of autonomous vehicles across diverse scenarios, including mixed-autonomy roads and multi-modal delivery systems that integrate drones and human carriers.

Results from the project have been widely disseminated, with several publications in reputable conferences and journals, and invited presentations at conferences, universities and industry research labs. The project included major education and undergraduate research activities. One graduate and one undergraduate course have been developed at UCSB with modules on reinforcement learning. Moreover, two undergraduate students have been trained on topics related to this project. 


 


Last Modified: 12/06/2024
Modified by: Ramtin Pedarsani
